document.docAuthor: Rosa, Paolo, Wei, Na-Sen, Notton, David & Xu, Zai-Fu
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Oriental genus Holophris Mocsáry, 1890 and description of the genus Leptopareia Rosa & Xu, gen. nov. (Hymenoptera, Chrysididae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the Oriental genus Holophris Mocsáry, 1890 and description of the genus Leptopareia Rosa & Xu, gen. nov. (Hymenoptera, Chrysididae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Holophris
Mocsáry, 1890 : 51
(as subgenus of
Elampus Spinola, 1806
). Type species:
Ellampus ( Holophris ) marginellus Mocsáry, 1890
, by original designation.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The genus
Holophris Mocsáry
is closely related to Omalus Panzer,
Philoctetes Abeille de Perrin
,
Pseudomalus Ashmead
, and
Leptopareia
gen. nov.
It can be separated from the latter four genera by the transpleural carina extending below propodeal angle ( Fig. 1B ) (extending to apex of propodeal angle in other four genera); head, in frontal view, with distinct convex upper profile ( Figs 4B , 5B , 6B ) (elliptical in
Leptopareia
, Figs 7B , 8B , 9B , 10B , 11B ); in lateral view, with distinct subgenal area ( Fig. 3B ) (indistinct in
Leptopareia
, Fig.3A ); double omaulus triangularly shaped ( Fig. 1B ) (subparallel in
Leptopareia
, Fig. 1C ). Moreover, it can be separated from
Philoctetes
and
Pseudomalus
by mesoscutum impunctate ( Figs 4D , 5D , 6D ) (punctate in
Philoctetes
and
Pseudomalus
), and MS bisected by elongated genal carina ( Fig. 3B ) (not bisected in
Philoctetes
). It can be separated from
Leptopareia
gen. nov.
also by elongate MS (1.0–1.5 MOD ) (0.2–0.5 MOD in
Leptopareia
), double omaulus triangularly shaped ( Fig. 1B ) (subparallel in
Leptopareia
( Fig. 1C )), and different wing venation ( Fig. 2B ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Mesopleuron and metapleuron, lateral view. A. Omalus aeneus (Fabricius); B.
Holophris marginella (Mocsáry)
;
C. Leptopareia borneana (Cameron)
.

FIGURE 2. Fore wing venation.
A. Leptopareia borneana (Cameron)
; B.
Holophris thailandica
sp. nov.

FIGURE 3 . Head, lateral view.
A. Leptopareia borneana (Cameron)
; B.
Holophris taiwana (Tsuneki)
. Arrow pointing to subgenal carina.

subSubSection.paragraph: Redescription. Mandible tridentate; scapal basin deep and smooth; face glabrous; head with upper profile distinctly convex in frontal view ( Figs 4B , 5B , 6B ); MS = 1.0–1.5 MOD and horizontally bisected by elongated genal carina; gena and subgena carinate ( Fig. 3B ); subgenal area swollen ( Fig. 3B ); temples <1 MOD ( Figs 4A , 5A , 6A ); occipital area, pronotum and mesoscutum medially impunctate ( Figs 4C , 5C , 6C ); pronotum laterally depressed; notauli indistinct ( Figs 4D , 5D , 6D ); mesoscutellum with two to four anterior foveae ( Figs 4D , 5D , 6D ); metanotum usually elongated in dorsal view, and rounded in lateral view; mesopleuron subquadrate with double carinate omaulus forming an acute angle ( Figs 1B , 4A , 5A , 6A ); TPC extending below propodeal angle ( Fig. 1B ); PA subparallel and not sharply developed, almost indistinct; tarsal claw with three to four teeth; fore wing with shortened C , Sc+R and M , and M considerably arched, pterostigma positioned at less than half length of anterior margin, rarely at half length ( Fig. 2B ); apex of T3 with wide semitransparent rim (usually ± 1 MOD ), without distinct median notch ( Figs 4F , 5F , 6F ).
Biology. Nothing is known about their hosts. Specimens are occasionally collected on leaves, in yellow pantraps and MT in forested areas.

Distribution.
Holophris Mocsáry
is mainly a tropical genus distributed in Afrotropical, Australian, Neotropical, and Oriental Regions.

Species included. At present, there are seven valid species of
Holophris
in the Old World; of which three are from Oriental :
H. marginella ( Mocsáry, 1890 )
,
H. taiwana ( Tsuneki, 1970 )
, and
H. thailandica
sp. nov.
; three are from Afrotropical:
H. coriacea ( Dahlbom, 1850 )
,
H. mochiana Strumia, 1995
, and
H. striata ( Edney, 1940 )
; and one from Australian Region:
H. insperata ( Mocsáry, 1914 )
.

Remarks. The gender of the genus name
Holophris
(resulted from the Greek words ὄλως [=entirely] and ὀφρύς [=margin]) is feminine and not masculine as supposed by previous authors.
